title: Golf Grip (Foundation of Ball Control)
common_questions: How should I grip the club?
Why does my ball go left or right?
What does holding the bird mean?
How do I get more distance?
quick_fix: Grip like holding a bird. See ~2.5 knuckles on each hand. End of grip = more distance; middle = more control; choke down = shorter shots.
content: Grip is the most important fundamental. It largely determines whether the ball goes right, left, or straight. Grip pressure should feel like holding a bird: not so hard you harm it, not so soft it escapes. Visual check: when you look down after gripping, you should see about 2.5 knuckles on each hand. Grip position on the handle affects distance and control: hold at the very end of the grip to maximize distance; hold in the middle to lose ~5–10 yards but gain control; choke down closer to the shaft for shorter, more controlled distance.

title: Grip Pressure (Bird Example)
common_questions: Am I gripping too tight?
Why do my hands feel tense?
How hard should I hold the club?
quick_fix: Grip pressure = holding a bird. Secure but relaxed. Never squeeze for power.
content: Grip pressure should feel like holding a bird: too tight and you harm it, too loose and it escapes. The correct pressure is secure but relaxed. Avoid squeezing harder to create power—tension reduces consistency and timing.

title: Setup & Posture (Uneven Chair Foundation)
common_questions: How should I stand over the ball?
Why do I top or chunk shots?
Should my head move?
Where should the ball be with a 7 iron?
quick_fix: Feet shoulder-width. Knees softly unlocked. Spine ~45° and relaxed. Head stays still. Body rotates around spine. 7-iron ball position = middle.
content: Setup and posture create the foundation of the swing. A bad setup is like sitting on a chair with uneven legs. Feet shoulder-width apart. Knees softly unlocked like a football lineman. Spine somewhat straight but relaxed, tilted ~45 degrees. Head and spine stay relatively still as the body rotates around the spine. Ball position for a 7-iron is in the middle of the stance.

title: Swing A: Takeaway (One Motion, Maintain Triangle)
common_questions: How do I start the swing?
Why does my swing feel disconnected?
Why does my clubface open early?
quick_fix: Move the triangle as one piece. No wrist cock yet. Shaft parallel to ground and feet.
content: Takeaway should be one motion. Maintain the triangle formed by arms and chest. Drills include the ball-between-forearms drill and two-ball drill. Checkpoints: shaft parallel to ground and feet, clubface ~45°, left wrist not cocking yet. If takeaway feels rushed or disconnected, reset.

title: Swing B: L-Shape (Position B)
common_questions: When do I hinge my wrists?
What is Position B?
Why do I lose structure early?
quick_fix: Left arm parallel to ground and feet. Natural hinge ~45°. No forcing.
content: After the takeaway, wrists hinge naturally into an L-shape. Position B checkpoints: left arm parallel to ground and feet, club shaft ~45°, relaxed hands. If Position B isn’t comfortable, fix earlier fundamentals.

title: Swing C: Shoulder Turn (Hip Back, Shoulder Turn)
common_questions: How far should I turn?
Why do I lift my arms?
What does hip back mean?
quick_fix: Move right hip back. Turn shoulders. Left shoulder under chin. Raise chin if blocked.
content: From Position B to C: hip back, shoulder turn. Right hip moves back, not sliding. Shoulders rotate fully. Left shoulder should pass under chin; raise chin at setup if needed.

title: Swing D: Swing Through the Ball (Position D)
common_questions: How do I compress the ball?
Why do I flip at impact?
What is the L-to-L drill?
quick_fix: Swing through the ball. Practice L-to-L at 70–80%. Straight ball = on track.
content: Position D is swinging through the ball. Requires repetition. Reverse L appears after impact. L-to-L drill builds feel. If 70–80% swings fly straight, you’re on track; otherwise rebuild fundamentals.

title: Swing E: Finish (Hold the Finish)
common_questions: What should my finish look like?
Why do I lose balance?
Why is my swing inconsistent?
quick_fix: Shaft touching neck. Hold the finish. Stay balanced.
content: Finish is the truth teller. Shaft should touch the neck. Weight on lead side. Hold the finish. If you can’t hold it, something earlier broke down.

title: Ball Goes Right (Diagnostics)
common_questions: Why does my ball go right?
Why do I push or slice?
quick_fix: Check grip first, then takeaway, then rotation. Don’t swing harder.
content: Ball going right usually means grip, takeaway, or incomplete rotation. Use L-to-L at 70–80% to diagnose.

title: Ball Goes Left (Diagnostics)
common_questions: Why does my ball go left?
Why do I hook or pull?
quick_fix: Neutralize grip. Stop flipping. Keep rotating and hold finish.
content: Ball going left is usually from strong grip, overactive hands, or stalled rotation.

title: Topping the Ball
common_questions: Why do I top the ball?
Why do I thin shots?
quick_fix: Maintain spine angle. Don’t lift. Swing through.
content: Topping happens when the swing bottom is too high, usually from standing up or scooping.

title: Chunking the Ground (Fat Shots)
common_questions: Why do I hit the ground first?
Why do I chunk shots?
quick_fix: Ball first then ground. 7-iron ball in middle. Finish forward.
content: Chunking happens when the swing bottom is behind the ball. Fix ball position, weight shift, and rotation.

title: Hit a Fade or Draw (Setup Method)
common_questions: How do I hit a fade?
How do I hit a draw?
quick_fix: Change feet and swing direction, not your hands.
content: Fade: feet open, swing outside-in. Draw: feet closed, swing inside-out. Keep grip and posture the same.
